citation.article-title: Rhodoferax fermentans gen. nov., sp. nov., a phototrophic purple nonsulfur bacterium previously referred to as the Rhodocyclus gelatinosus-like group.

p.s: Description of Rhodoferax fermentans sp. nov.
Rhodoferax fermentans (fer.men'tans, L. part.adj, fermentans fermenting)
Cells are curved rods, 0.6 to 0.9 Î¼m in diameter, and motile by means of polar flagella.
Multiply by binary fission.
Gram negative.
Growth is possible by photosynthesis, aerobic respiration, and fermentation.
Photoorganotrophy with various organic compounds as carbon sources is the preferred mode of growth.
No reduced sulfur compounds serve as energy sources for photoautotrophic growth.
Thiamine and biotin are required as growth factors.
Ammonium salts and glutamate but not nitrate serve as nitrogen sources.
Gelatin is weakly hydrolyzed.
Color of photosynthetic cultures is peach brown.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids with spheroidene, spirilloxanthin, and OH-spheroidene as major components are present.
Intracytoplasmic membranes may be absent.
Major fatty acids are 16:1 and 16:0, and 3-OH acids with 8:0 predominating are present.
Q-8 and RQ-8 occur as major quinones.
Membrane-bound fumarate reductase activity with FMNHz as electron donor is found.
The G + C content of DNA ranges from 59.8 to 60.3 mol% (HPLC).
Source: ditchwater and activated sludge.
Type strain: FR2, which has been deposited in the Japan Collection of Microorganisms (JCM), RIKEN, Wako, Japan, as Rhodoferax fermentans JCM 7819.
